title: Thread Revisited: Why do we think it is an image of Jesus on the Shroud of Turin?
post: I really appreciate the comment of Maria about the fact that if the Shroud was done in the Middle ages by a fanatic who wanted to reproduced the Passion of Christ in order to produce a relic (what a crazy idea, but it’s there’s very a slim possibility there anyway that we can’t disregard completely), then you can bet your house that the images we see on the Shroud would have been very different.  In the Middle ages, nobody knew that the Roman drove the nails in the wrist instead of in the palms.  This fact alone is enough to understand that the Shroud came from the Antiquity instead of the Middle ages.  And there’s also the very particular and typical wounds (with dumbell shapes) that came from a Roman flagrum that nobody in the Middel ages would have been aware of.  I can keep on with others facts like that for a long time.  Look at all the artistic depictions of the Passion of Christ made in the Middle ages and you’ll see that this burial cloth don’t come from this period of time…
author: Yannick Clément
